Subjective: Stress-related symptoms for months, daily for last 2 weeks. Main symptoms: body tension, stiff muscles, rapid breathing, and heart palpitations. Palpitations occur spontaneously at rest (e.g., in bath, at night), last ~30 min. Triggers: high-stress job as a new doctor in internal medicine (understaffed, long days). Impact: Difficulty falling asleep due to worrying about work; sleeps ~6 hours/night. Negatives: No chest pain, dizziness, light-headedness, or irregular heartbeat. No symptoms on exertion. Social: Recently graduated doctor. Good social support from friends/housemates (also doctors). Finds it difficult to say no. Request: Rule out physical cause (e.g., anemia) and talk to a professional.
Objective: BP: 120/60. HR: 65 bpm. SpO2: 98%. RR: 14 breaths/min. Lungs: Clear breath sounds bilaterally, no abnormal sounds. Heart: Normal heart sounds, no murmurs.
Assessment: Stress-related symptoms, likely secondary to work overload. Plan to rule out somatic causes.
Plan: 1. Diagnostics: Blood tests ordered for hemoglobin, thyroid function, liver function, and kidney function. 2. Referral: Appointment with mental health nurse. 3. Advice: Actively build in moments of relaxation, maintain a regular sleep schedule, consider contacting occupational health doctor for potential work adjustments. 4. Follow-up: Check blood results in 2 working days. Return if symptoms worsen or concerns arise.
